thread.title: Ex-Premier League striker Nile Ranger could be jailed after admitting online banking fraud
thread.title_full: Ex-Premier League striker Nile Ranger could be jailed after admitting online banking fraud

author: Georgina Stubbs
title: Ex-Premier League striker Nile Ranger could be jailed after admitting online banking fraud
text:
Nile Ranger arriving at court before admitting one charge of conspiracy to defraud (Photo: Central News) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Ex- Newcastle United striker Nile Ranger has pleaded guilty to online banking fraud after a woman had more than £2,000 taken from her account. 
The former Premier League player admitted one charge of conspiracy to defraud at a hearing at Wood Green Crown Court. 
Now 25 and playing for Southend United, Ranger appeared in court alongside two others - Reanne Morgan, 18, and Aseany Duncan, 19, both from Enfield, north London. 
The court heard that Ranger's charge related to an incident on February 18 2015 when he "conspired with persons unknown to defraud Diane Bloss, by obtaining her personal online banking details and transferring by way of an online transaction £2,090.23 from an HSBC account to a Santander account". 
According to the Crown Prosecution Service's website conspiracy to defraud carries a maximum jail term of 10 years. 
Dressed in a green jacket and dark jeans, Ranger pleaded not guilty to a second count of money laundering. Ranger in a Newcastle United shirt (Photo: Action Images) He has played for a string of clubs in the Football League since then (Photo: PA) 
Prosecutor Catherine Rabaiotti told the court that charge will lie on file, while Morgan and Duncan pleaded not guilty to the same two counts. 
Duncan is also accused of possessing an article for use in fraud, namely a mobile phone containing the personal banking information of 500 people, which he pleaded not guilty to. 
Former England under-19 player Ranger, from north London, left the Magpies in 2013 after loan spells at Barnsley and Sheffield Wednesday. 
Since then he has spells at Swindon Town and Blackpool, before moving to Southend last year. Only five years ago Ranger was playing in Europe for Newcastle against Bordeaux (Photo: Getty) 
Requesting a pre-sentence report for Ranger, Angus Bunyan, defending, told the court: "He is 25 years old and although he has some previous convictions, the only serious one was 10 years ago or more." 
Addressing Morgan and Duncan, Judge Peter Ader warned them about the consequences of not appearing in court for the trial at Wood Green Crown Court. 
He said: "(It is a) bit like the other team do not turn up for the match. They are going to lose. Do you follow? 
"It is not a threat, I'm just telling you how it is." 
He later asked them if they could remember the provisional date for their trial. The court heard that Nile Ranger has "some previous convictions" (Photo: Andy Commins) 
When they did not respond, he said: "It may be the most important thing in your lives. It could be the difference between going to prison or being free." 
Morgan replied: "April 24?" 
Judge Ader said: "Yes, well done." 
Ranger will be sentenced after the trial. 
Conspiracy to defraud can be heard only at the Crown Court. It is an offence at Common Law which means it is an offence created by previous decided cases. 
It is punishable by up to 10 years’ imprisonment or a fine or both, although sentences of the maximum length are quite rare, and are usually only given in the most serious cases. Like us on Facebook
